title: 113_hr5431
content: The Act titled "Isolating ISIS Act" allows for sanctions on foreign financial institutions engaging in specific transactions. The "Isolating ISIS Act" allows the Secretary of the Treasury to prohibit or impose strict conditions on foreign financial institutions opening or maintaining correspondent accounts in the US if they engage in specified activities. Foreign financial institutions can face sanctions if they knowingly facilitate transactions for ISIS, engage in money laundering for ISIS-related activities, or provide financial services to support ISIS. Foreign financial institutions can be sanctioned if they knowingly assist in or facilitate transactions related to ISIS, including acting as intermediaries or providing financial services for such activities. Penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act apply to those violating prohibitions related to ISIS transactions. The Secretary of the Treasury will create regulations for enforcement. Waivers can be granted by the Secretary of the Treasury in consultation with other officials. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with other officials, may waive prohibitions on foreign financial institutions for up to 180 days if it is in the national security interests of the United States. A report must be submitted to congressional committees explaining the reasons for the waiver. The Secretary of the Treasury may waive prohibitions on foreign financial institutions for up to 180 days if it is in the national security interests of the United States. A report must be submitted to congressional committees identifying foreign central banks engaging in sanctionable activities. The Secretary of the Treasury can waive sanctions on a foreign financial institution for up to 180 days if it benefits national security. A report must be given to congressional committees identifying foreign central banks involved in sanctionable activities. Sanctions can be applied if the institution stops engaging in specified activities or shows progress in stopping them, with assurances from the relevant government. The foreign financial institution must provide assurance that it will not engage in prohibited activities in the future. Definitions for terms like "account" and "financial institution" are provided in this section. The term "foreign financial institution" is defined as per section 1010.605 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations, including a foreign central bank. "Money laundering" refers to activities outlined in section 1956(a) of title 18, United States Code. The Secretary of the Treasury may further define terms in regulations under this section. IMPOSITION OF SANCTIONS ON US PERSONS ENGAGING WITH CERTAIN FOREIGN ENTITIES. The President will impose sanctions on US persons engaging with certain foreign entities by submitting a list of individuals who have knowingly engaged in specified activities. This includes transactions with foreign persons involving the transfer of goods or services. The President will impose sanctions on US persons engaging with certain foreign entities by submitting a list of individuals who have knowingly engaged in specified activities, including transactions involving the transfer of goods or services to or from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. This applies regardless of whether the activity is carried out under a contract or agreement entered into before or after the enactment of this Act. The President may exclude a person from the list if they certify that the person has ceased or made significant efforts to stop the sanctionable activity. The President may exclude a person from the list if they have taken significant steps to stop the sanctionable activity and provide reliable assurances of future compliance. The President must update the list as new information becomes available, submitting it in unclassified form with a possible classified annex for public availability. The unclassified portion of the list required by paragraph (1) will be publicly available on the websites of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of State. The President must impose sanctions on individuals on the list, including restrictions on foreign assistance and procurement by the United States Government. The President may impose sanctions on foreign persons who are not United States individuals or entities, including restrictions on procurement of goods or services. Additional sanctions can be imposed in accordance with the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The term "person" includes natural persons, corporations, business associations, partnerships, trusts, and governmental entities operating as a business enterprise. The term "United States person" refers to individuals or entities within the United States. The term "United States person" includes natural persons who are U.S. citizens or owe allegiance to the U.S., as well as corporations or legal entities organized under U.S. laws where U.S. citizens own more than 50% of the entity's capital stock or beneficial interest. SEC. 4. REGULATORY AUTHORITY. The President must issue regulations within 90 days of this Act's enactment. Notification to Congress is required 10 days before regulations are issued. SEC. 5. TERMINATION. SEC. 5. TERMINATION. This Act will end 30 days after the President certifies to Congress that ISIS is no longer a designated terrorist organization, listed in the Executive Order, and poses no threat to US national security. SEC. 6. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not affect US intelligence activities. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "Islamic State of Iraq and Syria" includes individuals whose assets are blocked under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The curr_chunk states that individuals identified as affiliates of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria and entities designated as foreign terrorist organizations are subject to certain restrictions.
